author: @scootscoot2k
text: for anyone wondering apparently the selectROI function is only available in cv 3.4+ (it could be 3.3 as well, I went from 3.2 to 3.4 and that fixed it for me)

author: @LetsDark
text: I would use cv::erode and cv::dilate to get rid of the flickering pixels. Normally, I apply erode two times with an 3x3 block and then dilate with a 5x5 or something like that. This should help to get rid of some noise and view the puck more clearly.

text: I generate background "bg.png"and add  ..... img = cv2.imread('bg.png',cv2.IMREAD_COLOR ) while 1:     _, frame = cap.read()     frame=cv2.subtract(img,frame)     img_crop = frame[int(r[1]):int(r[1]+r[3]), int(r[0]):int(r[0]+r[2])] ..... THX for output.avi

author: @meinderth8240
text: Cool, looking forward to the next video. It feels a little unnecessary to find the standard deviation and compare it to the distance of each pixel in each frame. The puck won't grow or shrink, so I would just cut off every pixel further away than, say, 30 pixels from the average. Also, wouldn't one pixel, just the center, be enough to train the arm?

author: @mortensentim511
text: You should level the table. Also, the ROI lets you roughly scale the data so you can work out how many pixels across the puck should be. You could use a fixed multiple of its size rather than a standard deviation to accept/reject data. The puck shouldn't be getting bigger and smaller, and the puck should be the dominant source of pixels in the filtered data so the average should always be fairly close.
